Agenda

This will be a tech and design focused session. We’ll co-work on our websites, try new designs, squash bugs, or just do some long-neglected digital housekeeping.

IndieWebClub is part of a growing world-wide network of meetups for everyone who wants to take back their web experience from social media silos, and own their online identities & content, or just want support with blogging!

entry.title: IndieWebClub #19
entry.content:
1600×900 61.1 KB

Agenda

Do you enjoy reading or writing reviews for the media you engage with (books/movies/games) on your blog? Why or why not? What makes for a good review? What do you accomplish by writing one? What are you looking for when you read a review of something? How do reviews work differently on the web vs. in print? Do they still have value in a world of abundance? Do they increase your enjoyment of the art you’re engaging with?

Following from the above, what do you feel about being overly critical, mean, or downright inflammatory in your writing on the web? It can be easy to get page views by writing something clearly inflammatory, but do you want to put your name on a post that comes off as angry or frustrated? What if your anger is justified? What if it’s valuable to write that post? How do you call something out without seeming like a person who just complains about things? How do you criticize a work of art/company/product/person constructively?

As usual, we will end the meetup with a prompt and a writing session. Bring a device you can use to write and post to your blog.

Agenda

Let’s begin 2026 by asking an existential question: what is a blog post, really?

The world of letters is full of different formats and genres of writing: essays, journalism, fiction, scientific papers, manifestoes, diary entries, travelogues, memoirs, biographies, news updates, and so much more.

How is a blog post different from all of these traditional forms of writing? Is it similar to one of these forms or an amalgamation of everything? Or does it stand on its own as a completely new form of writing in the digital age?

We will also discuss strange intimacies people share on their website, as a form of archival and note keeping.

Agenda

This will be a writing focused session. Our agenda for this week’s discussions is:

  1. Footers! It’s a design element that doesn’t get enough attention, so let’s talk about it. What have you put at the bottom of your website? Navigation? A contact form? Badges? Social media links?
  2. Styles of personal blogging: from super raw to super polished, there’s a broad spectrum in terms of how you express yourself on the IndieWeb. From writing style and voice to typography and layout, many elements come together to form what we call “style”. Let’s talk about our personal style when it comes to showing up online.
